Explain convolutional neural networks in the context of this course. Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
Describe a practical use case where AutoML is applied. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Give an example that illustrates ML monitoring concretely. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Give a concise definition of reinforcement learning. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What are the key ideas behind gradient descent? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Give an example that illustrates ML agents concretely. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about pooling layers? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.

Why is recurrent neural networks important in modern machine learning systems? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Give an example that illustrates real-time machine learning concretely. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Explain transformers and self-attention in the context of this course. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Give a concise definition of train–serve skew. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Give a concise definition of pooling layers. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

What are the key ideas behind LSTM networks? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How does softmax regression relate to other concepts in this course? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Explain LSTM networks in the context of this course. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Give an example that illustrates overfitting and underfitting concretely. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Describe a practical use case where ML monitoring is applied. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Give an example that illustrates model-centric vs data-centric iteration concretely. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about activation functions? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Why is feature stores important in modern machine learning systems? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

Give a concise definition of logistic regression. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
Explain feature stores in the context of this course. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.

Explain model-centric vs data-centric iteration in the context of this course. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about logistic regression? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.

How would you explain ML monitoring to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How does transformers and self-attention relate to other concepts in this course? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Give a concise definition of logistic regression. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
How does recurrent neural networks relate to other concepts in this course? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
What are the advantages of understanding model-centric vs data-centric iteration well? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What are the advantages of understanding backpropagation well? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
Give a concise definition of feature stores. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Give a concise definition of AutoML. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How does reinforcement learning relate to other concepts in this course? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Explain ML monitoring in the context of this course. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.

Give an example that illustrates transformers and self-attention concretely. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Give an example that illustrates overfitting and underfitting concretely. Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
Explain pooling layers in the context of this course. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Give an example that illustrates LSTM networks concretely. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.

Give a concise definition of reinforcement learning. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Why is train–serve skew important in modern machine learning systems? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Give a concise definition of activation functions. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What are the advantages of understanding gradient descent well? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Explain feedforward neural networks in the context of this course. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How does unsupervised learning relate to other concepts in this course? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about real-time machine learning? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What are the advantages of understanding train–serve skew well? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How would you explain softmax regression to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How does unsupervised learning relate to other concepts in this course? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Describe a practical use case where softmax regression is applied. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
How does feature stores relate to other concepts in this course? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What are the advantages of understanding real-time machine learning well? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How would you explain reinforcement learning to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Why is activation functions important in modern machine learning systems? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about feedforward neural networks? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Describe a practical use case where logistic regression is applied. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Describe a practical use case where overfitting and underfitting is applied. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
How would you explain linear regression to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
Explain LSTM networks in the context of this course. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about feedforward neural networks? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Why is pooling layers important in modern machine learning systems? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

Why is transformers and self-attention important in modern machine learning systems? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

What are the key ideas behind gradient descent? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Give a concise definition of model-centric vs data-centric iteration. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Give a concise definition of gradient descent. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about recurrent neural networks? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Explain supervised learning in the context of this course. Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
How would you explain recurrent neural networks to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Why is ML monitoring important in modern machine learning systems? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Why is backpropagation important in modern machine learning systems? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Describe a practical use case where linear regression is applied. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Give a concise definition of overfitting and underfitting. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Describe a practical use case where ML agents is applied. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Describe a practical use case where feature stores is applied. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Why is gradient descent important in modern machine learning systems? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Explain model-centric vs data-centric iteration in the context of this course. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the advantages of understanding AutoML well? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Describe a practical use case where softmax regression is applied. Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
How would you explain pooling layers to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Explain ML monitoring in the context of this course. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Why is reinforcement learning important in modern machine learning systems? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Explain recurrent neural networks in the context of this course. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Explain real-time machine learning in the context of this course. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about transformers and self-attention? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

What are the key ideas behind logistic regression? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

Give a concise definition of model-centric vs data-centric iteration. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How would you explain softmax regression to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
How would you explain train–serve skew to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
How would you explain convolutional neural networks to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What are the key ideas behind linear regression? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about unsupervised learning? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.

What are the advantages of understanding overfitting and underfitting well? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.

Why is logistic regression important in modern machine learning systems? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.

Give a concise definition of feature stores. Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

What are the key ideas behind LSTM networks? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How does feedforward neural networks relate to other concepts in this course? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Why is supervised learning important in modern machine learning systems? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
How does feedforward neural networks relate to other concepts in this course? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Give a concise definition of LSTM networks. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about LSTM networks? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How does model-centric vs data-centric iteration relate to other concepts in this course? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Give an example that illustrates train–serve skew concretely. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Describe a practical use case where pooling layers is applied. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.

What are the advantages of understanding overfitting and underfitting well? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about unsupervised learning? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Give an example that illustrates supervised learning concretely. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Why is overfitting and underfitting important in modern machine learning systems? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Give a concise definition of gradient descent. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about supervised learning? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Why is reinforcement learning important in modern machine learning systems? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
What are the advantages of understanding backpropagation well? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about reinforcement learning? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

What are the advantages of understanding real-time machine learning well? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about logistic regression? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How does model-centric vs data-centric iteration relate to other concepts in this course? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Describe a practical use case where backpropagation is applied. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about pooling layers? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Give an example that illustrates feature stores concretely. Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about convolutional neural networks? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about train–serve skew? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Describe a practical use case where recurrent neural networks is applied. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Give a concise definition of gradient descent. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about feedforward neural networks? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Explain serverless ML in the context of this course. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the key ideas behind AutoML? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Why is AutoML important in modern machine learning systems? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Why is linear regression important in modern machine learning systems? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Explain feedforward neural networks in the context of this course. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What are the advantages of understanding pooling layers well? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Why is gradient descent important in modern machine learning systems? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
How would you explain pooling layers to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
Explain AutoML in the context of this course. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Give a concise definition of softmax regression. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Give a concise definition of ML monitoring. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
How would you explain LSTM networks to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Give a concise definition of feature stores. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.

How does model-centric vs data-centric iteration relate to other concepts in this course? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Explain real-time machine learning in the context of this course. Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
Explain reinforcement learning in the context of this course. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about transformers and self-attention? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

How would you explain overfitting and underfitting to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.

Describe a practical use case where activation functions is applied. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How would you explain unsupervised learning to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Give a concise definition of logistic regression. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.

What are the key ideas behind feedforward neural networks? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What are the advantages of understanding overfitting and underfitting well? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Describe a practical use case where convolutional neural networks is applied. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about AutoML? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
What are the key ideas behind logistic regression? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Give a concise definition of real-time machine learning. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Give an example that illustrates reinforcement learning concretely. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What are the advantages of understanding gradient descent well? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What are the advantages of understanding linear regression well? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about ML monitoring? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the advantages of understanding supervised learning well? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Describe a practical use case where real-time machine learning is applied. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How would you explain transformers and self-attention to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Why is convolutional neural networks important in modern machine learning systems? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the key ideas behind overfitting and underfitting? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
What are the advantages of understanding feature stores well? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How does ML monitoring relate to other concepts in this course? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What are the key ideas behind recurrent neural networks? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Describe a practical use case where reinforcement learning is applied. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
How would you explain model-centric vs data-centric iteration to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about logistic regression? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Give a concise definition of feedforward neural networks. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
How would you explain ML agents to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
How does train–serve skew relate to other concepts in this course? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Explain linear regression in the context of this course. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Why is pooling layers important in modern machine learning systems? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
How would you explain logistic regression to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How does linear regression relate to other concepts in this course? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Why is pooling layers important in modern machine learning systems? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Why is transformers and self-attention important in modern machine learning systems? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.

How does train–serve skew relate to other concepts in this course? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Describe a practical use case where ML monitoring is applied. Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?

Why is overfitting and underfitting important in modern machine learning systems? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

How does AutoML relate to other concepts in this course? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Why is feature stores important in modern machine learning systems? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Give an example that illustrates LSTM networks concretely. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
How does logistic regression relate to other concepts in this course? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Give an example that illustrates backpropagation concretely. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.

What are the advantages of understanding supervised learning well? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Give a concise definition of ML monitoring. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
How would you explain softmax regression to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

Explain backpropagation in the context of this course. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What are the key ideas behind gradient descent? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the advantages of understanding ML agents well? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How does activation functions relate to other concepts in this course? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about train–serve skew? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.

Explain feedforward neural networks in the context of this course. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.
