Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
What are the advantages of understanding model-centric vs data-centric iteration well? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How does recurrent neural networks relate to other concepts in this course? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Explain linear regression in the context of this course. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Why is backpropagation important in modern machine learning systems? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Explain overfitting and underfitting in the context of this course. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What are the key ideas behind LSTM networks? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the key ideas behind overfitting and underfitting? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How does pooling layers relate to other concepts in this course? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
What are the key ideas behind softmax regression? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
How would you explain AutoML to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
How does logistic regression relate to other concepts in this course? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

Explain supervised learning in the context of this course. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Explain softmax regression in the context of this course. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the key ideas behind real-time machine learning? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How does LSTM networks relate to other concepts in this course? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Explain serverless ML in the context of this course. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Give a concise definition of AutoML. Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
How would you explain LSTM networks to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the advantages of understanding backpropagation well? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
Describe a practical use case where LSTM networks is applied. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What are the key ideas behind unsupervised learning? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Give a concise definition of transformers and self-attention. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about logistic regression? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Why is train–serve skew important in modern machine learning systems? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Give a concise definition of unsupervised learning. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What are the key ideas behind ML agents? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Why is linear regression important in modern machine learning systems? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
What are the key ideas behind convolutional neural networks? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What are the advantages of understanding recurrent neural networks well? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Explain transformers and self-attention in the context of this course. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Give an example that illustrates pooling layers concretely. Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about activation functions? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
How would you explain reinforcement learning to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the advantages of understanding model-centric vs data-centric iteration well? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about ML monitoring? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What are the key ideas behind linear regression? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the key ideas behind ML agents? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
What are the key ideas behind LSTM networks? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
How would you explain supervised learning to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What are the advantages of understanding feedforward neural networks well? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
How does gradient descent relate to other concepts in this course? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Why is AutoML important in modern machine learning systems? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Give a concise definition of softmax regression. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Why is AutoML important in modern machine learning systems? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Describe a practical use case where pooling layers is applied. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How would you explain feedforward neural networks to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Give a concise definition of feature stores. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about recurrent neural networks? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Why is activation functions important in modern machine learning systems? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Give a concise definition of serverless ML. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Describe a practical use case where ML agents is applied. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Explain gradient descent in the context of this course. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Explain activation functions in the context of this course. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about ML monitoring? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
How does transformers and self-attention relate to other concepts in this course? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
How would you explain recurrent neural networks to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
How does supervised learning relate to other concepts in this course? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the advantages of understanding ML monitoring well? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Explain logistic regression in the context of this course. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Why is ML monitoring important in modern machine learning systems? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How would you explain reinforcement learning to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What are the key ideas behind softmax regression? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What are the key ideas behind LSTM networks? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

How would you explain serverless ML to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Give a concise definition of feature stores. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

How would you explain gradient descent to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Why is transformers and self-attention important in modern machine learning systems? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Why is reinforcement learning important in modern machine learning systems? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about serverless ML? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Why is unsupervised learning important in modern machine learning systems? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Give a concise definition of reinforcement learning. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What are the advantages of understanding LSTM networks well? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
What are the advantages of understanding overfitting and underfitting well? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about transformers and self-attention? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Give a concise definition of softmax regression. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Why is linear regression important in modern machine learning systems? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Why is train–serve skew important in modern machine learning systems? Can you also mention one typical pitfall?

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, can you also mention one typical pthis conceptfall?
Explain recurrent neural networks in the context of this course. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Give an example that illustrates unsupervised learning concretely. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Give a concise definition of ML monitoring. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Describe a practical use case where overfitting and underfitting is applied. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Give an example that illustrates feature stores concretely. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
What are the advantages of understanding AutoML well? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Describe a practical use case where real-time machine learning is applied. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.

How does activation functions relate to other concepts in this course? Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
How would you explain backpropagation to a fellow student who missed the lecture? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Why is feedforward neural networks important in modern machine learning systems? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Describe a practical use case where logistic regression is applied. Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

Why is activation functions important in modern machine learning systems? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
How does linear regression relate to other concepts in this course? Relate it to deployment and MLOps concerns.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

In practice, relate this concept to deployment and mlops concerns.
Explain gradient descent in the context of this course. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
How does serverless ML relate to other concepts in this course? Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Give an example that illustrates overfitting and underfitting concretely. Emphasize intuition rather than formalism.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

In practice, emphasize intuthis conception rather than formalism.
Explain real-time machine learning in the context of this course. Briefly compare it to an alternative approach.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

In practice, briefly compare this concept to an alternative approach.
Why is supervised learning important in modern machine learning systems? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Describe a practical use case where logistic regression is applied. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
Give a concise definition of ML monitoring. Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
Explain recurrent neural networks in the context of this course. Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about activation functions? Try to connect it to regression and classification tasks.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

In practice, try to connect this concept to regression and classification tasks.
What are the advantages of understanding train–serve skew well? Include an example from industry or real-world applications.

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

In practice, include an example from industry or real-world applications.
